unit_learning_outcomes.description: Understand and appreciate self as an early childhood professional, and as a learner.
Identify key characteristics of early childhood teachers and contexts.
Demonstrate increased skills of investigation and the ability to synthesise ideas.
Describe contemporary issues surrounding the pedagogy of professional practice.
Articulate an understanding of curriculum decision making and change.
Use library resources and information technology to enhance learning.
Understand the historical context and theoretical perspectives that influence contemporary early childhood education and care.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Weekly readings related to lecture and tutorial content

enrolment_rules.description: 40cp at 1000 level or above including (ECH113 or ECHE1130)

assessments.description:
Part A: In groups give a presentation explaining one aspect of the Early Years Learning Framework (EYLF) to a parent audience. 
Part B: Each group member will individually write a brief parent newsletter explaining the same aspect of the EYLF in a written format. 
(Presentation 10 minutes)
(Newsletter 1000 words)

assessments.assessment_title: Analysing Early Childhood Curriculum and Pedagogy
assessments.description: Write an essay exploring aspects of early childhood curriculum and pedagogy (1800 words)
Write a report examining the use of digital documentation platforms in early childhood settings and providing recommendations for their use (1200 words)

data.subject_search_title: ECHE2200 - Early Years Curriculum and Pedagogy in the Australian Context
data.description: This unit introduces students to the theoretical and philosophical trends underpinning early childhood pedagogy. Students explore the historical origins of early childhood curriculum and examine the principles and practices that influence contemporary approaches to teaching and learning with young children. Students will be introduced to philosophical principles including equity, diversity, ethics and critical thinking. In addition they will examine issues of professional judgment and curriculum decision making.
